No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served, or allowed to be used in or on the premises of billiard rooms or any place operated in connection therewith, except if such premises or establishment is an establishment which is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages and derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross revenues from the sale of products or services other than alcoholic beverages; provided, however, that if alcoholic beverages are sold by the drink for consumption on the premises of a billiard room, the governing authority of a local government may prohibit the sale, serving, or use of alcoholic beverages therein unless the establishment derives at least 75 percent of its revenue from the sale of products or services other than alcoholic beverages; and no local government may prohibit billiard rooms or the playing of billiards in any business which neither sells alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises nor engages in package sales of such beverages nor allows alcoholic beverages to be consumed on the premises. (Code 2003, § 32-216(2)) Sec. 10-465. - Gambling. It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, or manager of any billiard or pool room open for public use to allow gambling of any kind to occur upon such premises. (Code 2003, § 32-216(8)) Sec. 10-466. - Minors. It shall be unlawful for any person having charge of or control of any pool room or billiard room open to the public to admit into such room any minor, whether for the purpose of playing billiards or pool or not. (Code 2003, § 32-216(5)) Sec. 10-467. - Clear view of premises required. The owner, operator, or manager of any billiard or pool room in the city shall not permit to be used on such premises any screens, shades, partitions, or other devices of like character which shall have the effect of obstructing the view through the windows or doors of the place where the billiard or pool tables are kept. (Code 2003, § 32-216(6)) Sec. 10-468. - Doors. The doors of all billiard or pool rooms licensed under this article shall be kept unlocked whenever the tables are in use, or when any person other than the proprietor or his agent is present in such place. (Code 2003, § 32-216(7)) Secs. 10-469—10-489. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - MASSAGE BUSINESSES[7] Footnotes: --- (7) --- State Law reference— Georgia Massage Therapy Practice Act, O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq.; local regulation of massage, O.C.G.A. §§ 43-24A-22, 43-24A-23.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 10-490. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Employee means any person over 18 years of age, other than a masseur, who renders any service in connection with the operation of a massage business and receives compensation from the operator of the business or patrons. License means the authorization granted by the mayor and city council to allow a person to engage in the business of massage in this city. Massage means any method of treating the superficial parts of a patron for medical, hygienic, exercise, or relaxation purposes by rubbing, stroking, kneading, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating with the hands or any instrument, or by the application of air, liquid, or vapor baths of any kind whatever. Masseur means any person who engages in the practice of massage as herein defined. The use of the masculine gender shall include in all cases the feminine gender as well. Masseur's permit means the permission granted by the mayor and city council to a person to engage in the practice of massage as defined herein. Patron means any person over 18 years of age who receives a massage under such circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he will pay money or give any other consideration therefor. Recognized school means any school or institution of learning which has for its purpose the teaching of the theory, method, profession, or work of massage, which school requires a resident course of study of not less than 70 hours before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of graduation from such school following the successful completion of such course of study or learning. (Code 2003, § 32-217(2)) Sec. 10-491. - Exceptions. Nothing in this article applies to the practice of massage therapy of a massage therapist who is issued a license under the provisions of O.C.G.A. title 43, ch. 24A. The provisions of this article shall not apply to hospitals, nursing homes, sanitariums, or persons holding an unrevoked certificate to practice the healing arts under the laws of the state, or persons working under the direction of any such persons or in any such establishment, nor shall this section apply to barbers or cosmetologists lawfully carrying out their particular profession or business. (Code 2003, § 32-217(9)) Secs. 10-492—10-520. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 10-521. - License required. Each person engaging in or carrying on the business of massage within the corporate limits of this city, as such term is defined in section 10-490, shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk/treasurer in the manner specified in this chapter. No municipality shall levy or collect any license, occupation, or professional tax upon practitioners of massage and physiotherapy except at the place where the practitioner maintains his principal office. No such levy shall exceed the sum of $200.00 per year or shall be assessed upon or collected from any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, or instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state. (Code 2003, § 32-217(1)) Sec. 10-522. - Application. Applications for a license to engage in the business of massage shall be made as provided in section 10-25, except that the application shall contain the following additional information: (1) The name, style, and designation under which the business or practice is to be conducted; (2) The business address and all telephone numbers where the business is to be conducted; (3) A complete list of the names and residence addresses of all masseurs and employees in the business and the name and residence addresses of the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business; (4) The following personal information concerning the applicant and the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business: a. Name, complete residence address, and residence telephone numbers; b. The two previous addresses immediately prior to the present address of the applicant; c. Written proof of age; d. Height, weight, color of hair and eyes, and sex; e. Two front-face portrait photographs taken within 30 days of the date of the application and at least two inches by two inches in size; f. The massage or similar business history and experience, including, but not limited to, whether or not such person previously operating in this or another city or state under license or permit has had such license or permit denied, revoked, or suspended and the reason therefor, and the business activities or occupations subsequent to such action of denial, suspension, or revocation; g. All criminal convictions other than misdemeanor traffic violations, fully disclosing the jurisdiction in which convicted, and the offense for which convicted, and the circumstances thereof; h. A complete set of fingerprints taken and to be retained on file by the police chief or his authorized representatives; and i. Information on educational background, including a diploma, certificate, or other written proof or graduation from a recognized school by the applicant or by the person who shall be directly responsible for the operation and management of the massage business, if such person graduated from such a school; (5) Such other information, identification, and physical examination of the person as shall be deemed necessary by the police chief to discover the truth of the matters herein required to be set forth in the application; (6) Authorization for the city, its agents, and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the license; (7) The names and addresses of three adult residents of the county who will serve as character references, with said references being persons other than relatives and business associates; and (8) Written declaration by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that the foregoing information contained in the application is true and correct, said declaration being duly dated and signed in the city. (Code 2003, § 32-217(3)) Sec. 10-523. - Public hearing. Upon the filing of an application for a massage business license, the city clerk/treasurer shall fix a time and place for a public hearing thereon. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant individually and to the general public by publication of notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality. (Code 2003, § 32-217(5)) Sec. 10-524. - Inspection of premises. (a) All premises proposed to be used by licensees hereunder shall be inspected by the police chief or his authorized representatives prior to the issuance of a license for the purposes of ensuring that such premises comply with all the building and sanitation requirements set forth in the regulations and laws of the city and have adequate ventilation, heating, and illumination. (b) The police chief shall provide for the periodic inspection of all massage businesses to ensure that such establishments continue to operate in full conformity with all regulations and laws of this municipality. (Code 2003, § 32-217(6)) Sec. 10-525. - Limitations on issuance. No license to engage in the business of massage shall be issued if the police chief or the city clerk/treasurer finds that: (1) The correct license fee has not been tendered to the city, or, in the case of a check or bank draft, has not been honored with payment upon presentation. (2) The applicant or the manager or other person principally in charge of the operation of the business has been convicted of any crime involving dishonesty, fraud, or allowing a person under the age of 18 years to come onto or remain on the premises of any massage business establishment, as masseur, employee, or patron. (3) Alcoholic beverages. No person shall sell, give, dispense, provide, or keep or cause to be sold, given, dispensed, provided, or kept, any alcoholic beverage on the premises of any massage business. (Code 2003, § 32-217(7)) Sec. 10-526. - License fee. The annual business license fee for persons engaging in the business of massage in this municipality shall be set by resolution of the council. (Code 2003, § 32-217(4)) Sec. 10-527. - Revocation/suspension of license and permit. Any massage business license or masseur's permit issued under this section shall be subject to suspension or revocation by the police chief for violation of any provision of this chapter, or for any grounds that would warrant the denial of issuance of such permit in the first place. The chief, upon such revocation or suspension, shall state his reasons in writing, specifying the particular grounds for such revocation or suspension. The massage business must also comply with O.C.G.A. § 16-6-17. (Code 2003, § 32-217(8)) Secs. 10-528—10-547. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - SIDEWALK CAFES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 10-548. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Access zone means that portion of the public sidewalk reserved for continuous unobstructed pedestrian traffic and ingress/egress to businesses and structures lining the public rights-of-way. Amenity zone means that portion of public sidewalk for siting of municipal streetscape elements, such as street trees, street lights, benches, trash cans, sign posts, etc.; approved sidewalk cafe areas; and designated street vending locations. Appearance zone means that portion of the sidewalk as approved for downtown beautification or business enhancement, including planters and benches, product display and sidewalk signs, tables and chairs, and literature racks. License means the sidewalk cafe license issued for the lawful use of the public property, specifically sidewalks, by restaurants. Licensee means the holder of a sidewalk cafe license under the terms and provisions of this article. Manager means the city manager, or his designee. Obstacle means any object or item whether situated upon or hanging over the right-of-way, including, but not limited to, noticeable changes in grade or paving materials. Public property means property owned, leased, or maintained by the City of Porterdale, including, but not limited to, streets, byways or rights-of-way, sidewalks, parking lots, lots of record with or without structures, parks, and easements. Restaurant means a commercial establishment characterized by table service where food and beverages are prepared, served, and consumed primarily within the principal building. The term "restaurant" encompasses cafes, grills, and lunch counters but excluding, without limitation, drive-in and drive-thru restaurants, as well as temporary, mobile, and freestanding food service vendors. For the purposes of this article only, the term "restaurant" shall also encompass confectionary and dessert shops. Restaurant facade means the front of the building, specifically the elevation containing the primary entrance of the restaurant, unless otherwise determined by the manager. Sidewalk means that portion of the right-of-way improved for use by pedestrians located between the curbline or the edge of an improved roadway and the adjacent property line. Sidewalk cafe means the use of a sidewalk cafe area for the service of food and beverage. Sidewalk cafe area means the area within the amenity zone for placement of cafe furnishings on the public sidewalk and of operation of a sidewalk cafe as an extension and incidental activity of a city licensed restaurant. Sidewalk frontage means the length of frontage along the property line of that portion of any building occupied by the licensed restaurant to which the sidewalk cafe is incidental. (Code 2003, § 32-218(2); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(2)) Sec. 10-549. - Purpose and authority. This article shall apply to the establishment, operation, and maintenance of all outdoor cafes within the City of Porterdale on public sidewalks. The purpose of this article is to promote the general economic development and atmosphere of the city for the benefit of businesses and citizens located there, and no right of individuals or individual businesses are created therein, and to create an aesthetic ambiance which will attract tourists to the Porterdale area. Further, this article is designed to ensure the primary purpose of the public rights-of-way by maintaining the efficiency of the pedestrian path for both safety and convenience. This section is adopted pursuant to the authority granted by the Official Code of Georgia Annotated and the Constitution of the state, for the purpose of maintaining the health, safety and welfare of the city, and to ensure that sidewalk cafe operations within the city on public property are conducted in a manner consistent with the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city. (Code 2003, § 32-218(1); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(1)) Sec. 10-550. - Fines and violations. The following minimum fines shall be imposed for violations of this article: (1) First citation: $100.00 fine. (2) Second citation (within one-year period): $250.00 fine and a seven-day suspension of sidewalk cafe operation. (3) Third citation (within one-year period): $500.00 fine and a 30-day suspension of sidewalk cafe operation. (Code 2003, § 32-218(12); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(12)) State Law reference— Limitation on penalties, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2). Sec. 10-551. - Exceptions. Outdoor dining areas on private property are not encompassed herein but are addressed in the official zoning ordinance and other city development regulations. (Code 2003, § 32-218(3); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(3)) Sec. 10-552. - Location by zoning district. No sidewalk cafe license shall be allowed except in areas as provided within the current official zoning ordinances regulating the location of restaurants. (Code 2003, § 32-218(7); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(7)) Sec. 10-553. - Incidental seating limitations. Seating in the sidewalk cafe area shall not exceed 30 percent of the seating in the restaurant to which the sidewalk cafe is incidental. No sidewalk cafe seating authorized herein shall be used for calculating seating requirements pertaining to the location of, applications for, or issuance of a license to operate a restaurant or to sell alcohol, nor shall sidewalk cafe seating be used to claim any exemption from any other requirements of any city, county or state codes, ordinances and/or laws. (Code 2003, § 32-218(8); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(8)) Sec. 10-554. - Pedestrian clearance. A reasonable space shall be reserved at all times for continuous unobstructed pedestrian traffic along the public sidewalk. This reserved access zone shall not be encroached upon even if it precludes a sidewalk cafe. Additionally, a minimum of one foot of unobstructed space shall be reserved at all times between any sidewalk cafe perimeter and the nearest obstacle, including, but not limited to, streetscape elements and the curb. (Code 2003, § 32-218(9)(A); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(9)(A)) Sec. 10-555. - Limitation on area. The area in which a sidewalk cafe is operated shall be located in the amenity zone, limited to the width of sidewalk frontage of the licensed restaurant. Only the approved sidewalk cafe area shall be used, and said area shall not be modified without the written consent of the manager. (1) The determination of whether and to what extent the sidewalk cafe interferes with the considerations outlined in section 10-586 shall be made by the manager at the time of application based on the characteristics of each proposed site. (2) For corner locations or where extreme right-of-way limitations exist, the manager may consider alternative areas of the same size or less in the immediate proximity for sidewalk cafe locations provided that the requirements of section 10-554 are met. (3) To allow for maximum sidewalk cafe potential in the city and where obstacles prevent the sidewalk cafe from utilizing the full width of the sidewalk frontage, the manager at his reasonable discretion may consider an extension of the sidewalk cafe equal to the area unable to be used because of the obstacle provided the adjacent area is not an area necessary to be clear for ingress/egress to another business or businesses, or for continuous, unobstructed pedestrian traffic; the adjacent area is not currently licensed as a sidewalk cafe area or a street vending location; and all other provisions of this article are met. The manager may also take into consideration the basis, not fact, of any objections proffered by an adjoining property or business owner. In no instance shall a sidewalk cafe area extension exceed 55 feet from the primary service entrance. (Code 2003, § 32-218(9)(B); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(9)(B)) Sec. 10-556. - Cafe furnishings. Cafe furnishings shall be limited to tables, chairs, and umbrellas, which are subject to the manager's reasonable approval. Only approved furnishings shall be located in the sidewalk cafe, and said furnishings shall not be modified without written consent of the manager. (1) Design. All furnishings shall be fire-retardant or manufactured of fire resistant material. Tables and chairs shall be metal and either black or dark green in color. Umbrellas shall be sized appropriately to be at least the same diameter as the table and not protrude beyond the side cafe area, shall be anchored with a weighted base, and shall be color coordinated with the restaurant to which the sidewalk cafe is incidental. (2) Condition. Cafe furnishings are to be kept clean, attractive, sanitary, safe, operable, in good repair, and in structurally sound condition at all times. If the manager judges any furnishing to be noncompliant with this section, said furnishing is subject to immediate removal by the licensee. (Code 2003, § 32-218(9)(C); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(9)(C)) Sec. 10-557. - Sanitation. It shall be the responsibility and duty of the restaurant to which the sidewalk cafe license is issued to maintain the area covered by the license in a clean, neat, and orderly manner at all times. The area shall be clear of litter, food scraps, soiled dishes and other debris, including, but not limited to, cigarette butts. The licensee shall daily remove from the public right-of-way grease, stains, food spots, etc., caused by the operation of the sidewalk cafe. (1) It shall also be the responsibility of the license holder to wash the sidewalk surface on which the sidewalk cafe is located no less often than once weekly and pressure wash upon request by the manager. (2) The licensee shall sweep the sidewalk and collect debris prior to pressure washing and shall maintain records of the date the sidewalk was pressure washed and by whom, and such records shall be open to inspection by the city. Pressure washing shall be conducted using water only and the use of cleaning agents is prohibited. (Code 2003, § 32-218(9)(D); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(9)(D)) Sec. 10-558. - Service and activity privileges. The following service privileges are also extended as part of the sidewalk cafe license: (1) Beverage and food. Any sidewalk cafe that serves beverages must also provide food service. No outside service of food nor beverages is permitted after 11:30 p.m. and all outside consumption shall cease at 12:00 midnight. Each table shall have a posting provided by the city to inform patrons of relevant downtown ordinances. If a restaurant to which a sidewalk cafe license is issued under this article sells alcoholic beverages, then, in addition to the other provisions of this article, the following shall apply: a. Sidewalk cafes are considered part of the restaurant premises and operated as an extension and incidental activity of a restaurant including both food and beverage service, provided that the restaurant to which the sidewalk cafe is licensed maintains valid business and pouring licenses under the applicable Georgia Law and the regulations of the city and maintains compliance with all sections of this article. b. Sidewalk cafes are exempt from any restrictions on open containers upon the restaurant obtaining a permit from the state department of revenue. However, all alcoholic beverages shall be served in clear containers (e.g., no beer bottles, taps, kegs, coolers, etc.). c. If an alcoholic beverage is served to a patron, the patron must be advised that he is not allowed to leave the premises of the sidewalk cafe area with the alcoholic beverage, except to go inside the restaurant to which the sidewalk cafe is incidental. Patrons shall not walk from one establishment to another with an alcoholic beverage. (2) Glass containers. The city reserves the right to suspend the privilege of using glass containers, including other types of ceramic serving vessels or plates, within the sidewalk cafe during any permitted special events or when streets are closed. The use of such containers will be revoked if an incident jeopardizes the health, safety and welfare of customers or the general public. (3) Smoking. Sidewalk cafes may not be designated as outdoor smoking. (4) Specific limitations. Licensees must comply with the following requirements: a. No encroachment at any time into the access zone provided for pedestrian travel and areas reserved for ingress, egress, and circulation. b. No relocation, alteration, or modification to the right-of-way, sidewalk surface, or streetscape elements. c. No furnishings used in connection with a sidewalk cafe shall be attached, chained or affixed to any tree, post, sign or other fixture or surface. d. No overnight storage, parking, or leaving any items on the sidewalk except for approved furnishings, which may be kept in the sidewalk cafe area at the licensee's risk. No use of the sidewalk cafe areas to stock or store tables, chairs, or other items not in use. e. No exposed flames or use of oil or torches. Small votives, where the flame is fully surrounded by a nonflammable container, are permitted. f. No use of streetscape elements such as public trash cans by licensee for either the sidewalk cafe or the restaurant. g. No use of the sidewalk cafe area to place, display, or sell items other than food or beverages. h. No signage in the sidewalk cafe area, upon furnishings, or on serving vessels. i. No extension of electrical cords to provide music, lighting, etc., to the sidewalk cafe areas. Nor shall a licensee allow sound or a device which produces a loud noise or use or operate any loudspeaker, public address system, radio, sound amplifier, or similar device in violation of the city noise regulations. The city reserves the right to decrease noise levels of businesses if affecting public activities in the area. j. No food preparation shall be allowed on the sidewalk. There shall be no cooking, storage, cooling or refrigeration or other equipment in the sidewalk cafe area. k. No sublicense of the sidewalk cafe area. No licensee shall, nor shall a licensee allow others, to use the sidewalk cafe area to place displays, vend, distribute information or display goods, or other activities other than those specifically permitted in this article. (5) Violations. Any violation of the above requirements, or state or local laws, can result in suspension or revocation of the license. Repeated offenses may result in denial of subsequent sidewalk cafe license applications. (Code 2003, § 32-218 (9)(E); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(9)(E)) Sec. 10-559. - Removal of furnishings. The manager at his reasonable discretion may require temporary removal for cleaning or special circumstances. If such temporary removals exceeds 30 days during a calendar year, the city shall apply a prorated credit to the licensee's account for each additional day the sidewalk cafe is subject to removal. The licensee shall not be entitled to any refund for the removal period nor shall the city be responsible for any costs associated with the removal or return of sidewalk cafe furnishings. (1) Temporary removal for cleaning. All tables and chairs of a sidewalk cafe shall be removed from the public sidewalk as notified by the city for right-of-way cleaning. The licensee shall be responsible for removing all sidewalk cafe furnishings at least one day prior to the date identified by the manager. (2) Suspension or modification of operation. The manager shall have the authority to require any sidewalk cafe operating in an area created by this section to suspend operation and/or clear such area, or to move or modify the location or operation of the sidewalk cafe without prior notice or prior hearing when in the reasonable discretion of the manager any such use, occupation, or obstruction may interfere with special circumstances such as: a. Any permitted special event; b. Any street, sidewalk, or utility construction; c. Any emergency situation; or d. The protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the public. (3) Failure to remove furnishings. Under subsections (1) and (2) of this section, and section 10-589, failure to remove all furnishings and other items associated with the operation of the sidewalk cafe shall result in a removal of such furnishings and other items by the manager. The licensee shall be responsible for all expenses incurred by the city for the removal and storage of such furnishings and other items. (Code 2003, § 32-218(9)(F); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(9)(F)) Sec. 10-560. - Americans with Disabilities Act. Any person or entity receiving a license hereunder agrees to comply with all the requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act and all other applicable regulations as currently existing or as may be hereafter amended. (Code 2003, § 32-218(13); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(13)) Secs. 10-561—10-583. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 10-584. - License required and fee; license non-transferable and expiration. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person or business to operate a sidewalk cafe in the city without having first obtained a license or to fail to comply with all provisions of this division. A sidewalk cafe license is valid for one year from January 1 to December 31. A new license shall be procured each year, which shall be the responsibility of the license holder. The application fee for the license shall be the fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and shall be paid at city hall upon the filing of an application for the license no later than December 15 of the preceding year. (b) No license shall be transferable or assignable to any person or other location. Licenses will expire upon transfer of ownership, change in use of facility, and on December 31 of each year, unless revoked or suspended prior to expiration. The issuance of the license shall not be construed, interpreted, or considered to grant or convey any property rights, any lease holder rights, or any interest in the public right-of-way. The provisions of this division are subject to change and amendment by the city from time to time. (Code 2003, § 32-218(4); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(4)) Sec. 10-585. - Items needed for license application; notification. An applicant for a license shall submit the following items for review: (1) A completed application form. (2) A copy of a valid city occupational/business license to operate a restaurant in front of which the sidewalk cafe is proposed to be located. (3) A copy of the current certificate of insurance in the amounts and categories required by section 10-587; (4) A scaled drawing identifying, at a minimum, the following: a. The restaurant footprint; b. The width of the sidewalk frontage, known as the restaurant facade, and the distance between the restaurant facade and the curb in front of the restaurant facade; c. The dimensions of the proposed sidewalk cafe; d. The distance between the proposed sidewalk cafe and the nearest obstacle around the perimeter of the sidewalk cafe; and e. The quantity, design, and materials of the proposed cafe furnishings for the sidewalk cafe. (5) A nonrefundable license application fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. The city manager, or his designee, shall process applications and ensure site sufficiency based upon the application materials in this section and observing considerations of section 10-586. The applicant shall not change, increase, or decrease the sidewalk cafe or modify its parameters as outlined in the application without written authorization from the manager. (Code 2003, § 32-218(5); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(5)) Sec. 10-586. - Consideration of license. In deciding whether or not to grant, renew, suspend, or revoke a license under this article, the manager shall consider the following: (1) Compliance by the applicant or license holder with the provisions of this division and all other relevant laws or ordinances, regulations and resolution of the city and any other governmental body or agency. (2) Payment record and status of occupation tax, alcohol license fees, or other monies owed by the applicant or restaurant submitting the license application. (3) The character and reputation of the applicant or license holder. (4) The conduct of the restaurant of the applicant or license holder. (5) The actual or proposed effect of the sidewalk cafe on the primary purpose and use of the public right-of-way, including, but not limited to, the efficiency and clearance of the pedestrian access zone; on-street parking; vehicular travel lanes; loading/unloading areas; hydrants and utility access; crosswalks and accessibility ramps; driveways and alleys; transit or bus service stops; and intersection visibility. (6) The actual or proposed effect of the sidewalk cafe given the proximate right-of-way area; sidewalk dimensions, materials, and existing condition; obstacles and obstructions; street signs; streetscape elements such as street trees, street lights, benches, trash cans, sign posts, etc.; and proximity of other sidewalk cafes. (7) The actual or proposed effect of the sidewalk cafe on nearby properties, including, but not limited to, the impact upon adjoining property owners and/or tenants as well as the proximity of nearby sensitive uses such as residential uses, healthcare facilities, lodging establishments, public buildings and restrooms, parks, and other areas which may be impacted by heightened pedestrian activity and traffic, noise, odor, smoke, litter, or property values and all other relevant considerations. (8) All other relevant issues related to the public health, safety, welfare, morals, interest, and convenience. (Code 2003, § 32-218(6); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(6)) Sec. 10-587. - Liability and insurance. (a) Except for actions arising out of the City of Porterdale's sole negligence, the licensee agrees to indemnify, defend, save, and hold harmless the city and its officers, officials, representatives, agents, and employees from any and all claims, liability, damages, or causes of action which may arise out of the license or licensee's service or activity regarding the sidewalk cafe area. (b) The licensee agrees to maintain during the entire license period, at its own expense, the following: (1) Commercial general liability in the amount of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. The city must be named as an additional insured on this policy, and an endorsement must be issued as part of the policy reflecting compliance with this requirement. (2) Workers' compensation and employer's liability as required by the State of Georgia. (3) All policies must be issued by companies authorized to do business in the State of Georgia and listed on the U.S. Treasury Circular 570. (4) The city must receive 30 days written notice prior to any cancellation, nonrenewal, or material change in the coverage provided. (5) The license must provide an original certificate of insurance as evidence that the above requirements have been met prior to the issuance of the license. (6) All proper permits required by the Newton County Health Department. (c) The licensee is responsible for immediate and proper workmanlike repair of any damage to public property caused by the sidewalk cafe. (Code 2003, § 32-218(10); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(10)) Sec. 10-588. - Additional conditions. The manager may, at his reasonable discretion under this article, place additional reasonable conditions upon the issuance of approval for a licensing order to ensure the protection of the public rights-of-way and the rights of all adjoining property owners and the health, safety, and general welfare of the public. (Code 2003, § 32-218(9)(G); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(9)(G)) Sec. 10-589. - Revocation or suspension of license. The approval of a sidewalk cafe license is conditional at all times. Said license may be revoked or suspended up to 12 months by the manager if it is found that: (1) Any necessary business or health permit/license/certificate has been suspended, revoked, or cancelled. (2) The licensee does not have insurance as described in section 10-587. (3) The licensee has violated this article, or any other city or state regulation. (4) The licensee has a history of violations of this article within a two-year period. (Code 2003, § 32-218(11); Ord. of 5-7-2012(3), § 32-218(11)) ARTICLE XIII. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT MACHINES
Sec. 10-590. - Gambling devices prohibited. Gambling devices, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20(2) are prohibited in the city, and the ownership, use, or transport thereof shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to state law, except as exempted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 (b) through (d). (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(A)) Sec. 10-591. - Gambling places prohibited. Gambling places, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20(3), are prohibited in the city, and the operation thereof shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to state law. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(B)) Sec. 10-592. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Amusement game room means any location as provided in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(b), (c) or (d) where one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are operated that permit noncash redemption as provided in O.C.G.A. § 16-25-35(d). Bona fide coin-operated amusement machine means the same as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70(b)(2)(A) and any applicable regulations of the State of Georgia. Examples of bona fide coin-operated amusement machines include, but are expressly not limited to, the following: • Pinball machines; • Console machines; • Video games; • Crane machines; • Claw machines; • Pusher machines; • Bowling machines; • Novelty arcade games; • Foosball or table soccer machines; • Miniature racetrack, football or golf machines; • Target or shooting gallery machines; • Basketball machines; • Shuffleboard machines; • Kiddie ride games; • Skeeball machines; • Air hockey machines; • Roll down machines; •Trivia machines; • Laser games; • Simulator games; • Virtual reality machines; • Maze games; • Racing games; • Coin-operated pool tables or coin-operated billiard tables as defined in O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1(3); and • Any other similar amusement machine which can be legally operated in Georgia. The term also means machines of any kind or character used by the public to provide music whose operation requires the payment of or the insertion of a coin, bill, other money, token, ticket, card, or similar object such as jukeboxes or other similar types of music machines. The term "bona fide coin-operated amusement machine" does not include the following: • Coin-operated washing machines or dryers; • Vending machines which for payment of money dispense products or services; • Gas and electric meters; • Pay telephones; • Pay toilets; • Cigarette vending machines; • Coin-operated scales; • Coin-operated gurnball machines; • Coin-operated parking meters; • Coin-operated television sets which provide cable or network programming; • Coin-operated massage beds; and • Machines which are not legally permitted to be operated in Georgia. Class B machine means a bona fide coin-operated amusement machine that allows a successful player to accrue points on the machine and carry over points won on one play to a subsequent play or plays in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d)(2);and (1) Rewards a successful player in compliance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d)(1) and (2); and (2) Does not reward a successful player with any item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i) or any reward redeemable as an item prohibited as a reward in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(i). Location means a business within the city that has complied with the provisions of this article. Location owner or location operator means an owner or operator of a business where one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public. Operator means any person, individual, firm, company, association, corporation, or other business entity that exhibits, displays, or permits to be exhibited or displayed, in a place of business other than his own, any bona fide coin-operated amusement machine in the state. Owner means any person, individual, firm, company association, corporation, or other business entity owning any bona fide coin-operated amusement machine in the state. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(C)) Sec. 10-593. - License required. No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of a location owner or location operator of an amusement game room, as those terms are herein defined, without first having obtained a license and without first having paid the applicable occupation tax required under this article. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(D)) Sec. 10-594. - Issuance of license. (a) Application for a license for operating an amusement game room within the corporate limits of the city shall be made to the city clerk upon a form to be supplied by the city clerk for this purpose. The license application shall include the following information: (1) Name, address, and age of the applicant and the date of the application; (2) Address or place where the bona fide coin-operated amusement machine or machines are to be offered to the public for play and the other business or businesses operated at that place or places; (3) Name and address of the owner of the machine or machines and a copy ofthe owner's master license; (4) Name and address of any other business owned or operated by applicant within the corporate limits of the city; (5) List of any other licenses or permits from the city held by the applicant. (b) Upon issuing a license for an amusement game room, the city official or employee shall provide the licensee with a copy of this article. The city shall not require a fee for licensure or registration of an amusement game room. A license issued in accordance with this article shall be valid until December 31 of the year in which the license was issued. The owner or operator of an amusement game room shall be required to pay occupation taxes in accordance with chapter 24, article II, of this Code. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(E)) Sec. 10-595. - Occupation tax required. No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of an owner or proprietor of amusement game room, as the term is herein defined, without first having completed the occupation tax certificate form, paid the required occupational tax, and without first having obtained the license required under this article. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(F)) Sec. 10-596. - Distance. Every amusement game room in the city shall comply with the proximity provision for businesses licensed to sell alcohol as set out in section 4-27. After a hearing, the mayor and council may waive the applicability of this provision to an individual location if no alcohol is served at such location. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(G)) Sec. 10-597. - Number of bona fide coin-operated amusement machines at a location. No amusement game room in the city shall offer to the public more than six Class B bona fide coin-operated amusement machines that reward the player exclusively with noncash merchandise, prizes, toys, gift certificates, or novelties at the same business location. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(H)) Sec. 10-598. - Notice requirements. (a) Every amusement game room shall post a conspicuous sign with the following or substantially similar language: "GEORGIA LAW PROHIBITS PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR WINNING A GAME OR GAMES ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR FREE REPLAYS WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; OR AWARDING ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY OF A VALUE EXCEEDING $5.00 FOR A SINGLE PLAY OF THIS MACHINE." (b) Every amusement game room shall post its business license or occupation tax certificate issued by the city conspicuously and permanently. (c) The owner or operator of a business location which offers to the public any bona fide coin-operated amusement machine that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) shall inform all employees of the prohibitions and penalties set out in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f) and (g). (d) The owner or possessor of any bona fide coin-operated amusement machine that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) shall inform each location owner or location operator of the business location where such machine is located of the prohibitions and penalties set out in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f) and (g). (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(I)) Sec. 10-599. - Compliance with O.C.G.A. provisions relating to master licenses, location licenses, and stickers for individual machines. Bona fide coin-operated amusement machines may be used in an amusement game room within the city only if the machines are owned by a person who holds a valid master license in accordance with Title 50, Chapter 27, Article 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, and each machine offered to the public for play has a valid permit sticker in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-27-78. In addition, the business owner where the machines are available for play by the public must pay a location license fee in order to obtain a valid location license in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-27-71(a.1). The city official in charge of issuing business licenses shall notify the state commissioner of revenue of any observed violation of O.C.G.A. § 50-27-71 or § 50-27-78. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(J)) Sec. 10-600. - Gross receipts from bona fide coin-operated amusement machines at a location; provision of monthly verified reports; penalties. (a) No location owner or location operator shall derive more than 50 percent of such location owner's or location operator's monthly gross retail receipts for the business location in which the Class B machine or machines are situated from such Class B machines; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to modify or waive the revenue requirements set out in section 4-1(b). (b) Each location owner or location operator shall provide to the city clerk a copy of each verified monthly report prepared in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-27-84, the provisions of said O.C.G.A. section being incorporated herein by reference. The location owner or location operator shall allow an annual audit of the reports to be conducted by the city clerk or his designee from the location owner or location operator. (c) For violation of this section, the city may fine an applicant or holder of a license, refuse to issue or renew a location license, or revoke or suspend a location license for single or repeated violations of this section in accordance with the provisions of section 10-601. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(K)) Sec. 10-601. - Penalties for violations by owners or operators of amusement game rooms. (a) In addition to penalties set out in the O.C.G.A. provisions for failure to comply with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 or the provisions of Title 50, Chapter 27, Article 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, the location owner or location operator of an amusement game room, after conviction in a court of competent jurisdiction, may be subject to the following penalties for violation of the provisions of this article: (1) First offense: Fine not to exceed Five Hundred ($750.00) Dollars for each violation. (2) Second and subsequent offenses: Fine not to exceed $1,000.00, and incarceration as permitted under section 4.13(c) of the City Charter for each violation. The fines and penalties listed in this subsection (a) for violation of this article may be imposed by the judge of the municipal court of the city. (b) In addition to the penalties set forth in subsection (a) of this section, upon conviction of a violation of the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), or (g), or upon conviction of a violation of the provisions of this article, the location owner or location operator may be subject to suspension or revocation of any alcoholic beverage license issued by the city for the location, and suspension or revocation of any other license issued by the city to the location owner or location operator, or for the location, in accordance with the following procedures: (1) The city clerk shall issue a notice of hearing before the mayor and city council, providing at least five days' prior written notice of a time, place and purpose of such hearing, including a specific statement of the charges upon which said suspension or revocation is being sought. Notice hereunder may be served personally to the license holder, or mailed via certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the location set out on the license application. (2) A hearing held before the council pursuant to this section shall be conducted informally, and the technical rules of evidence shall not apply. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. The holder of the license sought to be suspended or revoked shall be entitled to be represented by legal counsel, if desired, shall be able to cross-examine any witness produced by the city, and shall be able to present witnesses and evidence on such license holder's own behalf. Pursuant to such hearing, a decision to suspend or revoke the license or licenses under consideration shall be upon a majority vote of the council hearing the evidence. The license holder shall be promptly notified in writing of the council's finding and decision affecting such person's license or licenses. (3) In the event the holder of a license which is suspended or revoked by the city seeks to appeal said suspension or revocation to the appropriate tribunal, the cost of preparing a transcript of the hearing proceedings shall be borne by the license holder and must be paid in full at the delivery of said transcript. (4) Due cause for the suspension or revocation of any license shall include, but not be limited to, a violation of any laws or ordinances, both state and municipal, governing the offering and operation of coin-operated amusement machines in the State of Georgia, or a violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating such business. In addition, and in the event one of the licenses made the subject of the hearing is a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages issued under the provisions of chapter 4, due cause shall also include those matters set out in section 4-30(d). (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(L)) Sec. 10-602. - Operating regulations. All businesses operating as an amusement game room under this article shall be subject to the following regulations: (1) Devices to be kept in plain view. All machines shall at all times be kept and placed in plain view immediately upon entering the premises where located, and be open and accessible to any person who may frequent or be in any place of business where such machines are kept or used. (2) Inspection. The chief of police shall inspect or cause the inspection of any place or building in which any such machines are operated or set up for operating, and shall inspect, investigate and test such machines as needed. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(M)) Sec. 10-603. - Licenses and permits nontransferable. (a) Licenses required in this article are nontransferable. All businesses that have bona fide coin-operated amusement machines on the premises shall display, in plain view, the current license issued by the city. (b) The issued license shall not be transferred to another owner at the same site within the city. A new owner or proprietor must first obtain a new license if he is going to operate in the same or different location in the city. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(N)) Sec. 10-604. - Enforcing officer. The chief of police or his designee is hereby designated as the enforcement officer and shall execute all requirements of this article. (Ord. of 10-7-2013, § 32-202(O)) ARTICLE XIV. - MOBILE FOOD VENDORS
Sec. 10-605. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commissary shall mean an approved catering establishment, restaurant, or other approved place in which food, containers or supplies are kept, handled, prepared, packaged or stored and also has obtained approval from the Newton County Health Department. Mobile food vendor shall mean a retail food establishment that reports to and operates from a commissary and is readily moveable, is a motorized wheeled vehicle, or a towed wheeled vehicle designed and equipped to serve food. (Ord. of 8-1-2016) Sec. 10-606. - License required; application for license. (a) Except as otherwise provided by law, it shall be unlawful for a mobile food vendor to sell, or offer for sale, food of any type without a license first having been granted under this section, except for sales at city-authorized events for which the mobile food vendor has obtained a permit from the city. (b) An application for a business license or a permit hereunder shall be submitted to the city manager or his or her designee setting forth all information required hereunder and in compliance with this article. The city manager or his or her designee shall develop a form of application for the purpose of compliance with this article. (c) The following information and materials shall be provided with each application for a mobile food vendor business license: (1) Name of the mobile food vendor; (2) Make, model, and license plate number of vending unit; (3) Owner's contact information; (4) Operator's contact information; (5) Type of vendor (street vending unit or sidewalk vending unit); (6) Copy of approved permit from the department of public health, or county board of health acting as agent of the department, or the Georgia Department of Agriculture; (7) List of operating locations and times; (8) Signatures from property owners indicating consent for the use of their property; (9) Signature of applicant indicating agreement to the listed requirements. (10) Payment of a regulatory licensing fee in the amount of $50.00. (Ord. of 8-1-2016) Sec. 10-607. - Requirements for and limitations on operation. (a) No mobile food vendor shall conduct business or operate in the public right-of-way, except during city-authorized events. (b) A mobile food vendor shall not operate on any private property without the prior written consent of the owner. (c) A mobile food vendor shall maintain a $1,000,000.00 liability insurance policy. Proof of current liability insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in Georgia, protecting the mobile food vendor, the public and the city from all claims for damage to property and bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operation under or in connection with the permit. Such insurance shall name the city as an additional insured and shall provide that the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the expiration date without 30 days advanced written notice to the city. (d) Unless approved for a specific location or event by the city manager or by his or her designee a mobile food vendor shall not make sounds or announcements to call attention to the mobile food vehicle either while traveling on the public rights-of-way or when stationary. At all times said mobile food vendor shall be in compliance with the City of Porterdale noise ordinance. (e) The license and all applicable health certificates under which a mobile food vendor is operating must be firmly attached and visible on the mobile food vendor or pushcart at all times. (f) Any driver of a mobile food vendor motorized vehicle must possess a valid Georgia driver's license. (g) Mobile food vendors are allowed only in nonresidential districts. The city manager or his or her designee for neighborhood events may grant variances in residential districts. (h) Mobile food vendors shall not be located within 15 feet of any street intersection or pedestrian crosswalk or ten feet of any driveway. (i) No sale or offer for sale shall be made by any mobile food vendor between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. unless such sale is in conjunction with a city-authorized special event or film production permit. (j) Vending structures shall not be left unattended or stored at any time on the open vending site when vending is not taking place or during restricted hours of operation. (k) The mobile food vendor shall comply with all state, federal and local health and safety regulations and requirements and shall obtain and maintain any and all licenses required by any other health organization or governmental organization having jurisdiction over this subject matter. (l) The following safety regulations shall apply to any and all motorized vehicles operating under this article or used for mobile retail food establishments: (1) Every vehicle shall be equipped with a reverse gear signal alarm with a sound distinguishable from the surrounding noise level. (2) Every vehicle shall be equipped with two rear-vision mirrors, one at each side, firmly attached to the outside of the motor vehicle, and so located as to reflect to the driver a view of the highway to the rear, along both sides of the vehicle. (m) The mobile food vendor may sell only food and non-alcoholic beverage items. (n) Notwithstanding any ordinance to the contrary, a mobile food vendor shall be allowed signage marketing and/or advertising the business of the mobile food vendor, provided that such signage meets the following requirements: (1) One portable menu and/or sandwich board sign that shall not exceed six square feet per side in size, that is located on the premises where the mobile vendor unit is operating, and displayed only during such time as the mobile food vendor unit is open for food sale operations; and (2) Signs safely affixed to or painted on the mobile food vendor unit so as to be flat against the surface of that mobile food vendor unit. (o) The area within which a mobile food vendor unit is operating shall, at all times, be kept clean and free from litter, garbage, rubble and debris. To that end, each mobile food vendor unit must provide a trash or garbage receptacle in which patrons or customers may place their litter or garbage. The receptacle shall be within ten feet of the mobile food truck unit. The receptacle must be adequate in size so waste does not begin to overflow from the receptacle. The operator of the mobile food vendor unit must remove this litter or garbage from the permitted location when he or she leaves the permitted location. (p) Each mobile food vendor shall have and maintain a hand-sanitizing station or provide hand-washing facilities for use by customers of the mobile food vendor. (q) Operation of any mobile food truck units must maintain a minimum distance of 200 feet from any building housing an established licensed eating and drinking establishment. This distance will be measured from the serving window in a straight line to the property line of the nearest bricks and mortar food establishment. If a food truck operates less the 200 feet from any building housing an established licensed eating and drinking establishment, they must have expressed and signed consent from all affected establishments. This provision shall not apply to mobile food vendor units operating by invitation of the city at city-authorized events. (r) A drive-through shall not be used at any mobile food truck unit. A person operating a mobile food truck unit shall not conduct business with or accept orders from any patrons or customers while such patrons or customers are in their motor vehicles. (Ord. of 8-1-2016) Sec. 10-608. - Indemnification agreement required. As part of the permitting process set forth herein, any person or entity receiving a permit set forth herein shall execute an indemnity agreement indemnifying and releasing the City of Porterdale, its agents, employees and elected officials from any and all liability against any and all claims, actions and suits of any type whatsoever. (Ord. of 8-1-2016) Sec. 10-609. - Term of license and renewal. A mobile food vendor license issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for a period ending on December 31 of the year issued. A mobile food vendor license may be renewed by following the process set out in section 10-606 above. (Ord. of 8-1-2016) Sec. 10-610. - Enforcement and penalties for violation. The provisions of this article may be enforced through the city's code enforcement procedures or as otherwise authorized in this Code and may be pursued by appropriate remedy in a court of competent jurisdiction. The remedies that the city may pursue for a violation of this article include: (1) Any violation of this article may be punished as provided for in section 1-7(c) of this Code; (2) Revocation of the business license of the owner or operator of the mobile food truck unit found in violation of this article; (3) Refusal of the city to renew the business license of the owner or operator of the mobile food truck unit found in violation of this article; (4) If code enforcement is utilized to enforce this article, a resulting code enforcement lien may be assessed against the private property upon which the mobile food truck operation operates or operated.
